speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the episodes of unresponsiveness, when they happen and how long they last?

speaker: Patient
text: They happen usually after I eat something, like yesterday I had a sandwich for lunch and then I started feeling funny.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the facial grimacing you experience during these episodes - does it seem to be related to a specific activity or stimulus, or is it more of a general, involuntary reaction?

speaker: Patient
text: It's hard to explain, but my face feels like it's being pulled or squished, and my mouth makes a funny taste, like mud.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me when these episodes of unresponsiveness started, approximately how often they occur, and if there's a pattern or trigger that seems to set them off?

speaker: Patient
text: I think they started a little while ago, maybe a month or two? They happen pretty often, like every few days. And, I don't know, sometimes it's just after I eat something, but sometimes I don't eat anything before...

speaker: Doctor
text:
So the facial grimacing seems to be quite intense, does it look like it's causing any discomfort or pain for you, and can you tell me if you've noticed any numbness or tingling sensations in your face or extremities during these episodes?



Also, when you're not experiencing these episodes, are you generally able to carry out daily activities without any issues, or do you have to make any adjustments to your routine?



Can you recall if there's been any recent change or stress in your life that might be contributing to these episodes?

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities while you're experiencing these episodes of unresponsiveness? Do you have to perform any specific tasks or activities that might be triggering these episodes, or are they more of a random occurrence?

speaker: Patient
text: I just kinda... fall down, I guess. I try to sit up, but I don't really know what's going on. Sometimes my brother catches me and helps me up, but I don't remember it afterwards.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your responses so far. Can you walk me through your daily activities when you're experiencing these episodes of unresponsiveness? Do you have any trouble with fine motor tasks, like writing or using utensils, or is it more of a loss of consciousness?

speaker: Patient
text: I try to do stuff, but it's hard. I might be playing with my toys or drawing, but then I just... stop. I don't know what's happening, and my brother has to help me. I don't remember anything after that.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you walk me through what happens right before an episode starts, is it something that you can anticipate or is it more sudden?

speaker: Patient
text: It's like... I'm eating or drinking something, and I get this weird feeling in my mouth, like a muddy taste. Then, I start to feel a little funny, like my head is spinning, and I get this weird, squished feeling in my face.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about the episodes of unresponsiveness, when they happen and how long they last? Specifically, do they seem to come on suddenly or do you have a warning sign before they start?



Also, you mentioned that the facial grimacing seems to be quite intense, does it seem to be affecting your speech or ability to communicate effectively during these episodes?



Can you describe the events that occur immediately after an episode of unresponsiveness, do you regain consciousness and are you able to continue with your daily activities after the episode has passed?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really have a warning sign, I just feel funny and then... I don't know, I just fall down, I guess. It happens really fast, I don't even feel like I'm losing consciousness, it's just like I just stop doing stuff and my brother helps me up afterwards.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about the episodes of unresponsiveness, do you ever have any memory of what happens during them or if you're able to recall anything after the episode has passed?



Also, when you're experiencing these episodes, do you feel like you're in a different environment or do you feel like you're still in your own surroundings?



Can you describe the facial grimacing in more detail, is it limited to one side of your face or does it involve both sides?

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about your daily activities while you're not experiencing these episodes of unresponsiveness? Are you able to work, engage in hobbies, or take care of yourself without any issues?



Also, I'd like to know more about your family medical history - have any of your relatives experienced similar episodes or conditions?

Please, don't worry about answering anything you feel uncomfortable sharing, this is all part of the process.

speaker: Patient
text:
I like playing with my toys and drawing, but sometimes I get really tired and my brother has to help me. I don't really like it when I have an episode because I don't know what's happening and I get really scared.

I'm not really sure about my family medical history, but my brother has had some weird episodes too, but he doesn't really know what's wrong with him either.

I don't really find any activities too hard to do when I'm not having an episode, but when I am, it's hard to focus on anything and I just feel really confused.

My heart beats really fast during an episode, and I can feel it pounding in my chest, and my blood pressure feels really high too.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the episodes of unresponsiveness, do they seem to be triggered by specific situations or environments, such as being in a crowded place or in a quiet space?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really know if it's triggered by specific situations, but sometimes I have them when I'm eating or drinking something, like I mentioned before. And, I think they happen more often when I'm doing things that require a lot of concentration, like playing with my toys or doing puzzles.
